title: Evolution of Experts in Question Answering Communities

author: Aditya Pal, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Minnesota

segmentation: Hi everyone, my name is Aditya and I'm going to talk about evolution of experts in online communities and so this is the work done along with Short Chang Anjo constant from University of Minnesota and in this work we perform temporal evolution, temporal analysis of users and Stackoverflow data set and we study different characteristics of these users, specifically how they evolve and we do this for experts.
So before that begin.
Let me motivate some of the prior work about that.
April Evolution and temporal analysis so it can put analysis, can present deep insights into users activity patterns.
So, for example, go at all analyze hourly patterns of users to find it.
Even though 8020 contribution rule applies, the top contributors participation is much flatter, flatter than the Power Distribution.
Similarly, Lou at all showed that temporal activity patterns can be used effectively to train better question routing algorithms to ensure that a question gets answered in a timely manner.
And our research focus has been to understand how expert user evolve overtime, especially in code.
In answering systems and to that effect, we seek answers to questions such as how do these experts evolve and how do they influence other community members?
What are the different evolutionary characteristics of these experts?
And can we identify these different kinds of experts?
And how reliably can we do that?
And can we improve expert identification techniques by taking user evolution into account?
So in order to perform this research, we considered Stack Overflow data set from August 2000.
To September 2010, and this data set consists of 1,000,000 questions asked by 165 K users and roughly 2.4 million answers provided by 156 K users.
So this data set does not come up with the expert labeling.
Hence we considered several different labeling criterias, one of which was selecting user more than 9 answers and picking top 10% of them with the highest reputation scores.
And we also tried some manual labeling criterias and also some other synthetic labeling criterias and scissors have been consistent across different labeling criterias.
So the first step in the temporal analysis is the construction of temporal time series of basic static features such as number of ants.
This member of Best Answers and so on, and in order to do this, we divide the data into biweekly buckets where the start of the first bucket is a time of the first question in the data set.
So this way we had like 70 biweekly buckets and the next step is basically construction of a relative time series, which is done by picking up first 26 active buckets of a given user.

And this active bucket Time series is normalized based on the activity of other users during the same time period, and this eliminates external biases such as increasing users increase in asker answers, and so on.
OK, so to begin with, let us try to estimate how does the experts influence the question askers.
And this is only possible if we do a temporary analysis with just a static analysis.
We could not see this and what we see in this figure is distributors actually a plot of best answer probability of experts as well as ordinary users.
So the blue curve is for experts and the red curve is for ordinary people.
So what do you observe here is that initially this probability was same for the two kinds of people, but overtime it diverge drastically.
So for experts it grew linearly, whereas for ordinary users it dropped rapidly initially and then state fix.
So intuitively we explain this observation based on the following hypothesis.
First one is that askers are very in selecting newcomers answers at best.
And Secondly, we see that experts get.

Motivated as we get to organize for their work and there has been some research work prior research work that can be used to justify both of these hypothesis and seeing them in effect in our successful QA system is actually quite interesting.
Next, we actually look at the in.
Students of experts on ordinary users, so to see this, we consider two scenarios.
One when an expert answers a question, another when no expert answers a question, then we measure the number of answers by ordering people to that question.
So the figure shows that initially ordinary users participated vigorously on questions answered by the Expo.
But overtime the participation propensity decreased, and this is primarily becausw.
Initially experts for not distinguishable from ordinary users as it did not have huge amount of contribution, so users was less intimidated.
But overtime as experts gained reputation scores, people started getting ordinary people getting started, getting more intimidated by them, an.
And there has been a prior research work which shows that users get biased from the name value of an expert and.

In this case, we argue that this name value can intimidate ordinary people from participating in the community, and in order to find evidences of it, we look at discussions in a meta Stackoverflow which is actually subsystem where people actually get talked, have generic discussions about Stack Overflow with the aim of improving it.
So I mean.
Train service are discussions where people state that enormous contribution by experts demoralized him a bit and several mid level people said that it's intimidating initially.
But with time one can adapt among experts and people said that, you know it's intimidating to answer a question asked by an expert.
And many people, including experts, they actually discuss about the merits and demerits of allowing easy questions to be answered by beginners.

So overall, this highlights the need of a research method or mechanisms which can be used to address the issue of intimidation of ordinary users while they are participating in the Community, and some of those men measures could be actually anonymizing the discussion on a question answering system for a short period of time so that users are not getting intimidated by who's actually participating on it and hesitate to participate.
So now let us see how experts influence one another.
So if we consider P as a probability.
An expert answer and this probability is roughly 0.44 stack overflow and let N be the number of answers to a question.
Then number of expert answers to that question should be a binomial distribution and we can use this binomial distribution to estimate the expected collaboration among the experts.
What we see is that the observed collaboration, which is actually the blue curve, is.
Actually it's in complete contrast with the red curve, So what it says is that a collaboration of eight or more experts is practically ruled out.
An experts are actually participating in isolation an this shows to some effect that expert.
But less likely to collectively collaborate to answer a question.
I'm one hypothesis which justifies his behavior.
Is that experts aim at maximizing their value to effort ratio.
So if an expert has already answered the question, then there is a probably diminishing return on their question even after putting more effort.
So it's better to avoid it, so that's the logic that an expert might follow.
So and and if we actually extend this ban, look at this analysis overtime.
We see that the probability and probability of 1 expert answering a question versus more than one expert answering a question what we see over here is that initially experts collaborated on more.

Such collaboration decline.
This effectively suggests mechanisms are needed which could address this problem.

And we found that cable six is a unique minimizer of this basic criteria, and we can safely choose the number of clusters in a data set to be 6.
And based on the six clusters, we can run the Gaussian mixture modeling, clustering and.

Or the cluster means for the Gmail clustering and we observe few dominant patterns in this figure.
The first dominant pattern we see is that the blue curve is a set of people who are consistently active that they are active on the site for the whole year.
The second is people who are initially active but later become passive, which is actually the red curve.
3rd we see initially passive and later active, which is actually the green curve an for different reasons we might be aiming to find out these users for example.
For question learning schemes, we argue that users who follow the C pattern are actually quite useful, and this is because they are active around the year.
So as a result, routing a question to them would increase the likelihood of that question getting answered in a timely manner.

Secondly, for finding users who are going to leave the system, it is beneficial to find people who are in E so that mechanisms are incentives can be provided to them so that they don't leave the system.
Thirdly, for nurturing and motivating people, experts in L Group are probably quite valuable as because these users could be activated sooner than later to achieve their potential.
So overall we see that not all experts evolve in the same manner.
And there are different kinds of experts and they are quite useful for different kind of objectives.

How reliably can we do that?

What we see over here is that different types of experts can be predicted with the F measure greater than .5 by using less than 20 weeks of the data.

Possibility which can be used for different objectives, and this result can be further improved by taking in other features of these people and by using more sophisticated machine learning models.
But the aim here is to show that automatic detection of these users is possible.
So far, we saw that temporal analysis of users enable us to visual.
It is a contrast between the ordinary users and the experts.
And here we actually compared the performance of expert identification methods based on basic measures such as number of answers, best answers, which are the prior state of art models for ex.

Parentification in comparison with methods based on temporal series of answers and best answers and what we see again is that the model based on temporal data improves over the model based on static data.
My 5 to 15%.

And this improvement indicates that evolution of users hold additional information about their expertise which that aggregates does not capture and hence using a evolutional data of experts is probably more beneficial for expert notification than just using their aggregate measures.
So to summarize the talk.
What we showed here is that experts influence best answer.
Selection of askers and this influence actually linearly grows as we see an for the ordinary people.
They actually decrease drastically and then there is a fixed.
If you look at the influence of experts on ordinary people, we see that the ordinary people get intimidated by experts to some extent.
As has been said in the testimonies of these people on Stackoverflow.

We also see that experts tend to avoid each other once they establish that you know the other person is also an expert so that they can actually maximize the value value to effort ratio that they have in there that they can achieve for themselves.
We also see that experts, not all experts involved with the same pattern.
There are different kinds of experts in the system, some which are consistently active zone which are initially active and later become passive.
Some which are initially passive and then later become active and we can identify all of these different kinds of experts quite early on with some satisfactory performance.
And Lastly, we see that expert identification techniques can be improved by is 5 to 15% by using their temporal data.
Instead of the static data.
And the major tip takeaways of the talk are that we can build interfaces that anonymizes user profiles initially on a question.
And this anonymization can be beneficial for the initial participation on these people an.
And of course, these profiles can actually be revealed later on after a lapse of time, but this would enable better participation by the people and lead to less intimidation intimidation.
Secondly, we see that there are different kinds of experts and they can be useful for different perspectives.
And Lastly, we see that the expert identification methods can be improved by using temporal data of people into account.
That's it, thanks a lot.
